 [1] , laser excitation [2] , or Compton scattering [3] .

Rewrite the following paragraph:

 We present an accurate and efficient fundamental-measure density-functional (FMT) approach to describe fluids composed by rigidly-aligned hard hexagons, which are relevant as model systems for liquid crystals or colloidal suspensions with anisotropic interactions.

Rewrite the following paragraph:
 The FMT is based on a decomposition into three different types of weighted densities that can be evaluated efficiently using fast Fourier transforms.

Rewrite the following paragraph:
 We show how this new FMT yields excellent results compared to Monte Carlo simulations over wide ranges of packing fractions and orientations of the particles.

Rewrite the following paragraph:
 In particular we find very good agreement between our theoretical predictions and simulation data at high packing fractions where previous approaches fail due to strong correlations among neighboring particles.

Rewrite the following paragraph:
 Finally, we demonstrate that our method also allows us to accurately predict structural properties such as pair correlation functions and orientational order parameters.

Rewrite the following paragraph:
 This work provides further evidence that FMTs provide a powerful tool to study complex fluids beyond simple spherical particle models.

Rewrite the following paragraph:
 The description of liquids and soft matter requires sophisticated methods as these materials often exhibit complex structures and dynamics.

Rewrite the following paragraph:
 Density functionals have been developed during recent years as promising tools to tackle many-body problems in statistical mechanics [1] .

Rewrite the following paragraph:
 They allow one to calculate equilibrium properties for interacting particles by minimizing a free energy functional with respect to the local number density distribution.

Rewrite the following paragraph:
 A particularly successful class of density functionals are so-called fundamental-measure density-functionals (FMD), which were originally introduced by Rosenfeld [2] .

 In their original form they only apply to fluids consisting of identical spheres but extensions to more complicated shapes like ellipsoids

 [4] , dumbbells [5] , spherocylinders [6] , or even patchy particles

 [7, 8] were were proposed recently.

Rewrite the following paragraph:
 We present an approach to extract the underlying physics of large sets of experimental data by using machine learning techniques and statistical analysis.

Rewrite the following paragraph:
 The method was applied on two different examples, namely the measurement of the electrical conductivity in doped semiconductors as well as the determination of the critical temperature Tc for superconductivity in cuprates.

Rewrite the following paragraph:
 In both cases we find that our results are consistent with theoretical predictions.

Rewrite the following paragraph:
 We show how this new technique can be used to identify unknown parameters or even completely new phenomena which cannot be predicted theoretically at all.

Rewrite the following paragraph:
 A central goal of modern science is to understand complex systems such as materials or living organisms through their fundamental building blocks.

Rewrite the following paragraph:
 To achieve this aim it is necessary to develop methods which allow us to analyze huge amounts in experimental data efficiently.

Rewrite the following paragraph:
 Here we propose a novel approach based upon machine learning algorithms combined with advanced statistical tools.

Rewrite the following paragraph:
 Our method is demonstrated on two examples: First, we study the dependence of the electrical conductivity on doping concentration in semiconductor compounds.

Rewrite the following paragraph:
 Second, we determine the critical temperature T c for superconductivity in high-temperature cuprate oxides.

Rewrite the following paragraph:
 For both problems we obtain results which agree very well to existing theories.

 The purpose for this article is to present an overview of some recent results in quantum field theory (QFT) on curved spaces with noncommutative coordinates.

Rewrite the following paragraph:
 The main motivation for studying QFTs on such spaces comes from string theories which were formulated as open strings attached to D-branes whose positions can be described by noncommuting matrices.

 We will show that it is possible to define a covariant derivative operator acting on fields living on the GroenewoldMoyal plane.

 Moreover we can discuss how one can construct gauge invariant actions for these fields.

 Finally we will study the action of the discrete symmetries C,P,T and CP T .

Rewrite the following paragraph:

 In particular we prove that there exist exactly two non-isomorphic Leonard triples for each n = 3m+1 and one non isomorphic Leonard triple for each n = 3(m+1).

 Finally, we give some applications of our results on Leonard triples to the theory of hypercubes.

 The main goal in this work was to study the effect of different types of initial conditions on the evolution of density perturbations in an expanding universe with a positive cosmological constant (dark energy).

Rewrite the following paragraph:
 We have used two methods to solve numerically the Einstein equations coupled to the matter fields:  the standard method based on the expansion of the metric tensor into spherical harmonics; and the new method developed by us that uses the expansion of the metric into Chebyshev polynomials.

Rewrite the following paragraph:
 In both cases we are considered three types of initial conditions: Gaussian random fields generated using the Zel'dovich approximation, Gaussian random fields generated using a fast Fourier transform algorithm, and white noise.

Rewrite the following paragraph:
 Our results show that all these models give similar predictions at late times when they are evolved up to z = 0.5.

Rewrite the following paragraph:
 However, there are some differences between them at early times.

Rewrite the following paragraph:
 These differences can been explained as follows:  the Zel'dovich model predicts larger fluctuations compared to other models because it does not take into account the pressure term in the fluid equation; the white noise model gives smaller fluctuations due to its statistical properties; finally, the Gaussian random fields obtained via the fast Fourier transform algorithm predict intermediate values.
